entry.title: New York surgeons perform world's first human eyeball transplant
entry.summary: Surgeons at NYU Langone Health in New York have successfully performed the world's first complete human eye transplant on a patient named Aaron James. The procedure, which took place in May, aims to enhance the overall cosmetic outcome by providing support to the transplanted eye socket and lid. While the patient's vision outcome remains uncertain, the transplanted eye appears healthy, marking a significant advancement in the field of medical innovation. This surgery provides scientists with an extraordinary opportunity to study and understand the healing process of the human eye.

entry.title: Donald Trump ally Steve Bannon faces skeptical court in bid to overturn contempt conviction
entry.summary: Steve Bannon, former senior adviser to Donald Trump, appealed his criminal conviction for defying a subpoena from a congressional panel investigating the Capitol attack. Bannon argued that he did not receive a fair trial because the judge barred him from making arguments central to his defense, including his claim that he did not have to comply with the subpoena due to executive privilege. However, the appeals court appeared skeptical of his argument, noting that much of the information sought by the committee was unrelated to his interactions with Trump.

The incident took place outside a private property in Gramercy Park. The two individuals have been charged with criminal mischief. The torn-down posters have been replaced with new ones, featuring images of the 240 hostages taken by the terror group. This act of vandalizing or removing the posters has been condemned as antisemitic and inhumane.

Ghazi was responsible for recruiting terrorists for Lashkar and played a role in radicalizing individuals who infiltrated into Kashmir. Pakistani agencies are investigating the killing and are considering local rivals and internal conflicts within Lashkar as possible motives. This killing adds to a series of recent setbacks for Lashkar and its parent organization, ISI.

entry.title: Bodies litter streets as fighting intensifies in Sudan
entry.summary: Violence and fighting have escalated in Sudan, particularly in the capital and in the western region of Darfur. Witnesses report seeing corpses in the streets, and there are concerns about ethnically motivated mass killings. The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and the Sudanese army are battling for control, with the RSF claiming control of all but one major city in Darfur. There have been reports of serious human rights abuses by the RSF and affiliated militias, and the US embassy in Khartoum has expressed deep concern.

entry.summary: Greece's state ombudsman is launching an independent investigation into the coast guard's handling of a maritime tragedy in June. The incident involved an overloaded boat carrying migrants trying to reach Europe, with hundreds feared to have drowned. The ombudsman's decision comes after the Greek coast guard denied initiating a disciplinary investigation. A military court is already conducting a preliminary investigation into the shipwreck, which resulted in 104 survivors and 78 bodies being recovered.

entry.title: Bank Of America Says US Government Debt Is On Track To Surpass $50 Trillion By 2033
entry.summary:
Business Insider: US government debt is on track to surpass $50 trillion by 2033. That means $5.2 billion is piling up every day.
¬† The US government's debt is on track to surpass $50 trillion by 2033, Bank of America said in a Tuesday note, citing data from the Congressional Budget Office.¬† * The US government's public outstanding debt is on track to surpass $50 trillion by 2033.¬† * The increase comes out to roughly $5.2 billion every day or $218 million every hour, Bank of America estimated.¬† * "Central banks may simply bail out governments in coming years via QE," BofA said.¬† US public debt outstanding currently sits at $33.6 trillion and is expected to surge by $20 trillion to $54 trillion within the next decade amid "fiscal excess in the 2020s," Bank of America investment strategist Michael Hartnett said. "US public debt is... more than the combined GDPs of China, Japan, Germany, and India," he wrote, adding that the outstanding debt is set to surge by $5.2 billion every single day, or $218 million every hour, for the next 10 years.
¬† Read more ....
¬† Update: US debt to top $50 trillion ‚Äì BoA (RT).
¬† WNU Editor: Interest on the US debt has now crossed $1 trillion a year .... US Debt Interest Bill Rockets Past a Cool $1 Trillion a Year (Bloomberg).

entry.title: How To Attract Investors To Your Business

entry.title: Israel agrees to 4-hour daily pauses in Gaza fighting to allow civilians to flee, White House says
entry.summary: Israel has agreed to implement four-hour daily humanitarian pauses in its offensive against Hamas in northern Gaza, according to the White House. President Joe Biden had urged Israel for a multi-day stoppage in the fighting to secure the release of hostages held by Hamas. While a formal cease-fire is not currently possible, Biden requested a pause of at least three days for negotiations. Israel will also open a second corridor for civilians to flee the conflict areas.

entry.title: Pakistan running out of lamination paper, unable to print passports
entry.summary: The shortage of lamination paper in Pakistan is causing delays in issuing new passports, leading to difficulties for citizens. The paper used for passports is imported from France, and the limited supply is causing a backlog in processing applications. Many individuals, including students and those planning to travel for work or leisure, are being affected by the delays. The government has assured that the situation will soon be under control, but there is skepticism among the public.

Chancellor Olaf Scholz and Jewish leader Josef Schuster spoke at an anniversary ceremony in Berlin and condemned the discrimination and antisemitism that still exists in Germany. The commemoration comes at a time when antisemitism is on the rise in Germany and across Europe, with many Jews living in fear and facing discrimination.

entry.title: U.S. Navy May Extend All Its Nimitz-Class Carriers For Another Deployment
entry.summary:
Nimitz-class carriers at sea The first-in-class USS Gerald Ford carrier operated alongside the Nimitz-class USS Dwight D. Eisenhower in October amid high tensions in the Middle East. Credit: Petty Officer 3rd Class Janae Chambers/U.S. Navy
¬† Aviation Week: U.S. Navy Considers Extending All Its Nimitz-Class Carriers¬† The U.S. Navy‚Äôs Nimitz-class carriers are about to turn 50. But given the demand for the carrier air wing and delays to the Nimitz-class replacement‚Äîthe Ford-class‚Äîthe USS Nimitz (CVN 68) itself is unlikely to retire as soon as expected.¬† The Navy‚Äôs fiscal 2023 budget has already called to extend the first-in-class CVN 68, commissioned in 1975, for another deployment cycle instead of decommissioning it in 2025 as previously planned. Service officials say the upcoming budget request could include a final decision on extending the next in the class, the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower, beyond its 2027 projected end-of-service date‚Äîthough extending just that ship likely will not be enough.¬† ¬†Read more ....
¬† WNU Editor: The US Navy is also looking to speed-up production of future aircraft carriers .... US Navy mulls timing of new double-carrier award amid Enterprise delay (Defense News).

entry.title: Are Hezbollah's Anti-Ship Missiles A Threat To The U.S. Navy?
entry.summary:
Hezbollah's anti-ship missiles, a little remedy for those pesky foreign warships in the Mediterranean pic.twitter.com/UGVr9XIZJI ‚Äî S p r i n t e r X (@SprinterX99880) November 6, 2023
Reuters: Hezbollah's anti-ship missiles bolster its threat to US navy¬† BEIRUT (Reuters) - Powerful Russian anti-ship missiles acquired by Hezbollah give it the means to deliver on its leader's veiled threat against U.S. warships and underline the grave risks of any regional war, sources familiar with the group's arsenal say.¬† Hezbollah leader Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah warned Washington last week his group had something in store for the U.S. vessels deployed to the region since war erupted last month between the Palestinian group Hamas and Israel, shaking the wider Middle East.¬† Two sources in Lebanon familiar with the Iran-backed group's arsenal say he was referring to Hezbollah's greatly enhanced anti-ship missile capabilities, including the Russian-made Yakhont missile with a range of 300 km (186 miles).
¬† Read more ....
¬† Update: Hezbollah anti-ship missiles increase threats to US warships: Reuters (Al Mayadeen)
¬† WNU Editor: Apparently the video that has been making the rounds on social media that shows Hezbollah's anti-ship missiles is an old one (see video below). But the question still remains. Are Hezbollah's anti-ship missiles a threat to the US Navy? My gut says yes.

CNN: US carries out airstrikes in eastern Syria targeting IRGC and Iranian-backed groups weapons storage facility¬† The US military conducted an airstrike on a weapons storage facility in eastern Syria used by Iran‚Äôs Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) and affiliated groups, the Pentagon announced on Wednesday.¬† ‚ÄúThis precision self-defense strike is a response to a series of attacks against U.S. personnel in Iraq and Syria by IRGC-Quds Force affiliates,‚Äù Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe President has no higher priority than the safety of U.S. personnel, and he directed today‚Äôs action to make clear that the United States will defend itself, its personnel, and its interests.‚Äù¬† The strike was conducted by two F-15s, Austin said.

entry.title: Ukraine Wants To Recruit Women To Fight In The War
entry.summary:
DNYUZ/New York Times: ‚ÄòIf Not Me, Who?‚Äô: As Ukraine Seeks Troops, Women Prepare for the Call¬† Halyna Vynokur, a clerk in a hardware store in Kyiv, was shouldering a firearm for the first time. Iryna Sychova, a purchasing manager at a department store, disassembled and reassembled the jumble of rods and springs in a Kalashnikov rifle.¬† They were among two dozen women who turned out in a forest near Kyiv one recent weekend for a course in firearms and urban combat, training that included shooting rifles, finding booby traps and throwing hand grenades. They were spurred by a sense of duty, they said, realizing they might some day end up on the front lines.
¬† Read more ....
¬† WNU Editor: Not surprised that Ukraine is going to recruit women to fight in the war. The average age for a soldier in the Ukraine army is 43 years old, and getting older. The Ukraine army is running out of male bodies to fight in this war, and they need new recruits. Since there are a lot of widows and mothers who have lost their sons and loved ones in this war, the Ukraine Army will (I predict) have no trouble tapping into this grief and anger for them to join.

entry.title: Should I Stay or Should I Go? Stay-Behind Force Decision-Making
entry.summary: The grinding Ukrainian military offensive during the summer of 2023 has been a frightful sight for undersized nations fashioning their own defensive strategies against Russia or China. Small nations invaded by numerically superior foes simply do not have the combat power to win a combined arms fight. To nullify this overmatch, out-gunned states require asymmetric options to deter and defend. If deterrence falters and the defense cracks, there are few options to prevent enemy consolidation of control. One irregular option, increasingly present in small-nation defense plans, is the so-called ‚Äústay-behind force.‚Äù¬† The purpose of a stay-behind force is plainly stated The post Should I Stay or Should I Go? Stay-Behind Force Decision-Making appeared first on War on the Rocks.

entry.title: Russia Withdraws From The Conventional Forces in Europe (CFE) Treaty
entry.summary:
The U.S. and its NATO allies served notice Tuesday that they will formally suspend their participation in a 1990 treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe, marking the demise of another landmark arms control agreement. https://t.co/X1T7ZrFLCa pic.twitter.com/qn3IOmBj73 ‚Äî Geopolitics & Empire (@Geopolitics_Emp) November 7, 2023
RT: Russia rules out new arms control deals with NATO
¬† There is no point in talks until the US-led bloc adopts more constructive and realistic positions, the Kremlin has said ¬† The Kremlin has formally withdrawn from a major Cold War-era arms control pact with the NATO military bloc, saying the outdated treaty was already dead for years and had completely ‚Äúlost touch with reality‚Äù in the modern world.¬† The Russian Foreign Ministry announced the move on Tuesday, saying the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe (CFE) had ‚Äúfinally become history‚Äù after prior steps to withdraw, the first of which dates back to 2007. While it originally ‚Äúplayed a certain stabilizing role,‚Äù the deal was largely ignored by NATO members and thus has ‚Äúceased to meet the interests of Russia,‚Äù the ministry said.
¬† Read more ....
¬† WNU Editor: This is the Kremlin's explanation on why they have decided to withdraw from the Conventional Forces in Europe (CFE) treaty .... By criticizing CFE treaty, US wants to shift West‚Äôs blame on Russia ‚Äî diplomat (TASS).¬† Russia Withdraws From The Conventional Forces in Europe (CFE) Treaty
¬† Russia Formally Quits Post-Cold War Arms Treaty With Europe -- Moscow Times¬† US must pull out of CFE arms treaty -White House -- Reuters ¬† NATO Freezes Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe -- VOA ¬† NATO Countries Suspend Participation In Cold War-Era Security Pact After Moscow's Withdrawal -- RFE ¬† NATO suspends key Cold War treaty after Russia pulls out -- DW ¬† NATO, US slam Russia for withdrawing from conventional arms treaty -- The Hill

entry.title: Biden administration urges US court to uphold asylum restrictions
entry.summary: The Biden administration is appealing a judge's decision to block a rule imposing new restrictions on asylum seekers at the US-Mexico border. The rule, which aims to limit asylum for migrants who entered the US illegally or passed through other nations without seeking protection, was deemed to violate federal immigration law. The government argues that the rule includes exceptions and is therefore valid. Immigrant advocacy groups represented by the ACLU challenged the rule.

entry.title: US says China reveals little in arms control talks
entry.summary: China and the United States engaged in arms control talks in Washington this week, marking the first such meeting since the Obama administration. While the discussions were described as constructive, no follow-up meeting has been scheduled. The talks aim to set a positive tone ahead of a possible meeting between Presidents Joe Biden and Xi Jinping next week. The US is concerned about China's nuclear arsenal expansion, but China did not provide substantive responses to US requests for transparency on its nuclear forces.

entry.title: Britain bans 'laughing gas' to curb anti-social behaviour
entry.summary: Starting from Wednesday, a ban on the recreational use and possession of nitrous oxide, commonly known as 'laughing gas', will be in effect in Britain. The government cited the drug's contribution to anti-social behavior and health hazards as reasons for the ban. Offenders could face fines or up to two years in prison, and the maximum punishment for dealing the drug has been doubled to 14 years. Nitrous oxide is the third most commonly used drug by 16 to 24-year-olds and can lead to anaemia, nerve damage, or paralysis with heavy use.

entry.title: Republican climate skeptic Ramaswamy to quit Paris deal if elected
entry.summary: Vivek Ramaswamy, a Republican presidential candidate, stated that he would withdraw the United States from the Paris climate accord if elected. He believes that the climate change agenda is a hoax and that global warming is not an existential risk. Ramaswamy argues that the US should not be part of the Paris agreement and that policies restricting fossil fuel usage are more harmful to humans than climate change itself. He also emphasized the importance of focusing on domestic policies rather than being the "global police.

entry.title: Brookfield zoo celebrates birth of shark pup through parthenogenesis
entry.summary: A shark pup has been born through parthenogenesis at Brookfield Zoo near Chicago. The baby epaulette shark hatched during the summer, and its mother has never shared a tank with a male. Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction. The birth adds to the zoo's diversity of life. The shark pup is currently two months old and measures approximately 6 inches. It has been eating well and will soon be visible to zoo visitors.In contrast, the epaulette shark pup has fared better and has recently made its public debut, captivating visitors in the zoo's Living Coast exhibit.

entry.summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) is organizing a competition to develop a robotic cargo capsule for transportation to and from the International Space Station (ISS). The capsule will be operated as a commercial venture by the competition winner, who will receive financial support and technical assistance from ESA. The selected company may also be tasked with upgrading the capsule for transporting ESA astronauts and potentially traveling to other destinations, such as the Moon. This competition model is inspired by NASA's successful approach of working with private companies.

entry.title: Zelenskiy proposes extending Ukraine's gas export ban
entry.summary: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy has proposed extending an export ban on Ukrainian natural gas for the whole of 2024, a presidential decree said on Tuesday. The export ban was introduced soon after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 and was then extended to cover 2023. The decree also urged the government to increase the capacity of Ukraine's gas transmission system "to ensure the import of natural gas and its accumulation in underground gas storage facilities".

entry.title: The Relentless Struggles of India's Seawall Mammas
entry.summary:
PURI, India, Nov 07 (IPS) - For more than 33 years, a group of strong-willed women from the village of Tandahara, India have kept their homes and village safe and plan to continue despite the unrelenting impacts of increasingly severe monsoons. ¬†The sun is high in the noon sky‚Äîhumidity unrelenting at 95 percent in this Indian sea-coast village. The monsoon has been deficient; rice paddies are yellowing on the edges from the salty surf misting in on them. Waves now break barely 200 metres from the farms and homes.

Read the full story, ‚ÄúThe Relentless Struggles of India's Seawall Mammas‚Äù, on globalissues.org ‚Üí

entry.title: US 'Criminal justice system is corrupt' says footballer CJ Stroud
entry.summary: Houston Texans rookie quarterback CJ Stroud, after leading his team to victory against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, used his post-game press conference to draw attention to his incarcerated father. Stroud expressed the challenges of balancing his role as a family man, a football player, and helping his father, who is serving a 38-year to life sentence. He highlighted the need for criminal justice reform and the deplorable conditions in some prisons, emphasizing the importance of treating prisoners as humans. Stroud hopes his father will one day be able to attend his games.

entry.title: 'Pathetic': Marjorie Taylor Greene attacks 'feckless Republicans' who voted against her
entry.summary:
She tried to censure and it came up short. Now she's shaming the names who didn't vote in favor. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) had willed a resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) for her attendance of a protest opposing the war in Gaza. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? "List of feckless Republicans that voted WITH Democrats to table my censure resolution against Rashida Tlaib," Greene said on Wednesday. "This is why Republicans NEVER do anything to stop the communists Democrats or ever hold anyone accountable!! PATHETIC."
She created a social media thread naming some of her friends in the House who didn't have what it took to vote with her. They include current House Speaker Mike Johnson, Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX), and Rep. Ken Buck (R-CO) who announced he wasn't running for reelection.
Earlier in the week, Greene preemptively lashed out after learning that her effort wasn't gaining a coalition in Congress. "I want to remind you, this happened on the same day Hezbollah declared a day of immense anger," she said. "And Rashida Tlaib organized with that group. And they did. They did protest, and they did an insurrection into our Capitol complex, stopping Congress and stopping the Senate." The media was quick to take notice of the lawmaker's swing and miss Wednesday. "Colleague Kelly Phares rpts 23 GOPers join Dems to table or kill effort to censure Dem MI Rep Tlaib," tweeted Chat Pergram. Melanie Zanona also tweeted: "motion to table ‚Äî aka kill ‚Äî MTG‚Äôs resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib just passed the House, with help of 23 Republicans."
And CNN's Manu Raju added that the effort to take on Tlaib quickly died tweeting: "House kills resolution to censure Rashida Tlaib. 23 Republicans voted with Dems. MTG offered the resolution."

entry.title: Republicans to join Dems in breaking Tuberville's blockade on military promotions: report
entry.summary: Sen. Tommy Tuberville's (R-AL) blockade appears to be coming to an end, according to an MSNBC report. Capitol reporter Ali Vitali said that a group of Republicans were going to take to the Senate floor and force a vote with Democrats to marginalize Tuberville's protest against military promotions that has led to a reduced military readiness for the United States, according to reports. After a discussion about the absurdity of the protest, host Nicolle Wallace said that she recalled the era when Republicans had to be supportive of the military or they'd be shamed by leaders like Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and the GOP speaker. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? Taking to social media, reporter Andrew Desiderio confirmed the reporting, saying that the floor actions will take place tonight, where they will ask for unanimous consent on ending the Tuberville blockade. He said that he was told it would be led by Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-AK). The news comes after reports that McConnell threatened Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) over his bill to stop corporations from being able to give money to campaigns. McConnell reportedly pointed to Hawley in the caucus lunch and said he wouldn't be there if it wasn't for the money from his Senate Leadership PAC. He went on to threaten any member who supported the bill with a primary. It's the first such action heard about from McConnell since he suffered serious injuries from a series of falls and then appeared to freeze at various public press availabilities.

entry.title: Tuberville's military blockade has 'added danger' after top Marine's heart attack: report
entry.summary: He drew a hard line in the sand, stalling hundreds of promotions of military brass. That line is budging. Officials are fuming at Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-AL) after it was discovered over the weekend that Marine Corps Commandant Gen. Eric Smith, who had been doubling as both the top No. 1 and No. 2 Marine Corps leader since July, suffered an apparent heart attack and was hospitalized on Sunday ‚Äî leaving a three-star general to hold the prestigious post, according to a report published by Politico. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? The potential overextension of Smith and the stalling of more than 300 critical leadership roles was iced out by Tuberville's blockade installed as a protest against the Pentagon's policy to permit time off and reimbursement for abortions. Now‚Ä¶

The complaint details the cases of those nine jo...

entry.summary: Eleven days after Hamas terrorists poured into southern Israel from the Gaza Strip, killing at least 1,400 people and kidnapping more than 230, New York Gov. Kathy Hochul arrived in Israel with a photo of a Long Island native in hand to give to the president of the besieged country. Hochul, the Democratic governor of a state that has the largest Jewish population in the world outside of Israel, told the media in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack that she wanted to ‚Äúbear witness‚Äù to the tragedy, show New York‚Äôs ‚Äúunwavering‚Äù support of Israel and make sure that missing New Yorkers such as Omer ...

entry.title: 'Neener-neenerism': Analyst shreds GOP's 'stupid and gross' conditions to fund Israel
entry.summary: House Republicans, lead by newly minted Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA), are demanding that the cost of the aid package to Israel be "offset" by $14 billion in cuts to IRS enforcement funding guaranteed in President Joe Biden's Inflation Reduction Act ‚Äî which is not only unrelated to the issue at hand, but experts say it would actually increase the deficit. The fact that Republicans are demanding an increase in tax evasion as their condition of supporting a key U.S. ally's military is not an accident, argued Talking Points Memo's Josh Marshall on MSNBC Tuesday, but a sign of how low the GOP has sunk. "I have to say, Josh, like, Mike Johnson rolling out, going after the IRS on a must-pass is past even a caricature, I can imagine, of a priority from the Republican House speaker," said anchor Chr‚Ä¶

entry.title: 'Desperate threat': Top Dems say Tuberville could be behind Marine leader's health scare
entry.summary: After Marine Corps Gen. Eric Smith suffered landed in the hospital Sunday following "an apparent heart attack," Senate Armed Services Chair Jack Reed (D-Rhode Island) alleged U.S. Senator Tommy Tuberville's (R-Alabama) military promotions hold may have contributed, Politico reports. Politico notes the Alabama senator "has maintained the blockade over the Pentagon's abortion travel policy, ensnaring more than 300 generals and admirals at the upper rungs of the armed forces." Reed told the news outlet, "One of the reasons, I think contributed to his condition was he was doing two jobs at once. I've read where he was working from 5 a.m. to 11 p.m. As a result, if he had, as is normal, an assistant, he could switch off." POLL: Should Trump be allowed to hold office again? Per the report, he ad‚Ä¶

When the aggression started in full swing, many people in the world expected that Ukraine would not hold out," Zelensky said in his daily address late on Tuesday. "Meanwhile, the colossal achievements of our people, of all our soldiers, are simply taken for granted." "Ukraine's success in the battle for the Black Sea will g...

entry.title: Spain's Princess Leonor swears allegiance to divided nation on her 18th birthday
entry.summary: By David Latona MADRID (Reuters) - Princess Leonor, the heir to Spain's throne, formally stepped into the spotlight by swearing allegiance to the constitution on her 18th birthday on Tuesday, though boycotts by leftist and separatist politicians underlined divisions over the monarchy. The ceremony in parliament marked her coming of age, meaning she will now directly become queen after her father King Felipe VI, assuming he does not go on to have any male children. The princess, who went to school in Wales and started three years of military training in Spain in August, vowed to uphold the law,...

entry.summary: NEW YORK ‚Äî A New York-based United Nations human rights official has resigned over the organization‚Äôs response to the situation in Gaza, which he described as a ‚Äútextbook case of genocide.‚Äù Craig Mokhiber, the director in the New York Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, announced his resignation in a letter shared publicly on Tuesday ‚Äî more than three weeks into the Israel-Hamas conflict. ‚ÄúThis is a textbook case of genocide,‚Äù he wrote in an Oct. 28 letter to Volker T√ºrk, the UN‚Äôs High Commissioner for Human Rights. ‚ÄúThe European, ethno-nationalist, settler colonial project in Pa...

entry.summary: After banning all air travel with neighboring Haiti in adiplomatic row over the construction of a canal on Haitian soil, authorities in the Dominican Republic have relaxed their stance. entry.summary: Washington (AFP) - The United States accused Russian President Vladimir Putin Tuesday of trying to use the Israel-Hamas war to reduce Western support for Ukraine, which it said requires continued backing from Washington to prevent Russia success. Hamas militants carried out a shock cross-border attack from Gaza this month that Israeli officials say killed more than 1,400 people, prompting Washington to rush military aid to Israel and sparking fears in Kyiv that backing for its war against invading Russian forces could suffer. "Putin is very much trying to take advantage of the Hamas attack on ...

entry.summary: The government of El Salvador is charging a new $1,000 fee for passengers from African countries that fly into its capital‚Äôs international airport, a measure that comes as countries in the Western Hemisphere aim to stem a record flow of migration across the region. entry.title: How Nicaragua is helping ‚Äì and charging ‚Äì Haitians who want to reach the United States
entry.summary: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti ‚Äì Across the street from the departure terminal at Toussaint Louverture International Airport in Haiti‚Äôs gang-plagued capital, hundreds of anxious travelers spill out onto the road from an overflowing parking lot, listening for their Nicaragua-bound flight to be called. As ticket agents in white shirts walk through the chaotic crowd, there is chatter about how many days some have been camping out and the desperation driving them to Managua, the new migration springboard for migrants seeking asylum in the United States. ‚ÄúThere is nowhere that is simple,‚Äù one young man says...

entry.title: Britain's King Charles begins Kenya visit steeped in 'painful' colonial history
entry.summary: By Duncan Miriri NAIROBI (Reuters) - Britain's King Charles begins a four-day state visit to Kenya on Tuesday, his first to a former colony, during which he plans to acknowledge "painful aspects" of a shared history that included almost seven decades of colonial rule. Accompanied by Queen Camilla, Charles arrived in the East African country overnight and will be received by Kenyan President William Ruto in the capital Nairobi on Tuesday morning. Buckingham Palace says the visit is a reflection of the two countries' close cooperation on economic development, climate change and security issues. ...

entry.title: Venezuela's top court suspends results of opposition presidential primary
entry.summary: By Mayela Armas and Vivian Sequera CARACAS (Reuters) - Venezuela's Supreme Justice Tribunal said on Monday it has suspended the results of an opposition presidential primary that took place this month, despite an electoral deal between the government and the opposition that allows each side to choose its candidate. The ruling could risk the wrath of the United States, which this month rolled back some oil and gas industry and bond trading sanctions in exchange for the electoral deal. The U.S. State Department has already said it will reinstate sanctions if the government of President Nicolas M...

entry.title: Kenyans urge King Charles III to formally apologize for colonial-era abuses
entry.summary: King Charles III didn‚Äôt receive the warmest of welcomes when he arrived in Kenya for a four-day state visit on Monday. Calls are growing for the British monarch to make a heartfelt apology for colonial era abuses as he and Queen Camilla tour the east African country. The tour is the first to a Commonwealth country since he succeeded his late mother, Queen Elizabeth, who died in September after a seven-decade reign. Buckingham Palace announced that King Charles would ‚Äúacknowledge the more painful aspects of the U.K. and Kenya‚Äôs shared history,‚Äù which includes the bloody Mau Mau rebellion of the...

Israel has expanded ground operations in Gaza as it seeks to punish Hamas for a deadly gun rampage three weeks ago that Israeli authorities say killed over 1,400 people. entry.title: UK prepares to host global leaders' gathering on AI
entry.summary: London (AFP) - The UK government will welcome foreign political leaders, tech industry figures, academics and others this week for a two-day summit billed as the first of its kind on artificial intelligence (AI). entry.title: Zelensky holiday home on Crimea auctioned off by Russian occupiers
entry.summary: The Crimean home owned by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's family has been auctioned off by the occupying Russian authorities, the Russian state news agency TASS reported on Monday. The 120-square metre apartment in the luxury resort of Yalta on the south of the peninsula went for 44.3 million roubles ($480,000), almost twice the starting bid. There were only two bidders. The official previous owner was Zelensky's wife Olena, who bought it in 2013, a year before Russia seized the peninsula. At the time, Zelensky was still working as an actor. The apartment has three rooms with a view o...

entry.title: Mitch McConnell on 'collision course' with new GOP speaker: report
entry.summary: Newly appointed House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) has a record of opposing military assistance to Ukraine. Since taking charge of the House, he has not outright said he will block Ukraine aid ‚Äî but he has made clear it will not be coupled to his planned aid package to Israel, claiming the latter is more urgent of a need. But if Johnson continues to obstruct Ukraine aid, he is headed for a "collision course" with his counterpart in Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), who is committed to continuing to defend Eastern Europe against Russian aggression, reported Politico on Monday. According to Burgess Everett, McConnell's outspoken lobbying efforts to sway Republican senators to passing Ukraine relief "is a sharp deviation from his usual more reserved, consensus-building approach" a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Heavy rains cause partial dam collapse, flooding in Norway
entry.summary: Storm Hans battered Norway with heavy rains Tuesday and Wednesday. Flooding of the Braskereidfoss power dam control room prevented the hatches from opening, causing a partial collapse and flooding downriver. The heavy rains provoked mudslides and swollen rivers which swept away some structures and flooded towns, requiring the evacuation of more than 3,000 people and isolating others.

entry.summary: Rains and winds are growing in southern South Korea due to a tropical storm that's expected to slam into major urban areas.

entry.title: 6 killed in Hawaii wildfires, Maui mayor says
entry.summary: Wildfires fanned by the winds of a distant hurricane devastated Hawaii's Maui island on Wednesday, killing at least six people,¬†Maui County Mayor Richard Bissen said at a news conference.

entry.title: Beijing's flooding death toll rises to 33, with 18 still missing

entry.title: Who is responsible for Turkey‚Äôs bad buildings?
entry.summary:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated. Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government‚Äôs earthquake response. entry.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.
entry.summary:
Getty Images
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy ‚Äî and how we can do the same with some of our own. Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons. That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia‚Äôs nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. ‚ÄúNearly every commercia‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live
entry.summary:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
What Turkey and Syria‚Äôs deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth. In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. ‚ÄúIt was like the apocalypse,‚Äù Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters. A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.¬† | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
